worklogs.comment:
tianchen92 commented on pull request #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693
 
 
   Related to [ARROW-6930](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6930).
   
   There is a lot of verbosity in the construction of Arrays for testing purposes (multiple lines of setSafe(...) or set(...).  We should start adding some static factory methods to make test setup clearer  and more concise.  A strawman proposal for BigIntVector might look like:
   
   static BigIntVector create(String name, BufferAllocator allocator, Long... values).
   
   Usage would be something like:
   
   try (BigIntVector input = BigIntVectorCreate("sample_data", allocator, 1235L, null, 456L),
         BigIntVector expected = BigIntVectorCreate("sample_data", allocator, 1L, null, 0L),)
   {    output = doSomethingWith(input);    assertThat(output).isEqualTo(expected); }
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jacques-n commented on issue #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693#issuecomment-544327961
 
 
   Couple thoughts:
   
   - This is really a form of builder. Let's keep them out of the core vector objects. They have no need to be inside those objects. (This also keeps the core objects cleaner). 
   - We really need to decide whether these are generally useful or for testing. If generally useful, let's make them for general purpose. If only for testing purposes, let's put the impl in a test package, not in the test directories, not the main directories
   - If we want to link so people can use from the existing vector classes (if we decide these are generally useful), let's keep it to something akin to BigIntVector.newBuilder() with the Builder object outside (but that is only if we think they are not for testing).
   - Let's support building with both boxed and unboxed types for primitives.
   
   In general, let's have these conversations before you go and write a couple hundred lines of code. Will waste less of your time.
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

jacques-n commented on issue #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693#issuecomment-544327961
 
 
   Couple thoughts:
   
   - This is really a form of builder. Let's keep them out of the core vector objects. They have no need to be inside those objects. They aren't accessing any internal apis and this keeps the core objects cleaner. 
   - We really need to decide whether these are generally useful or for testing. If generally useful, let's make them for general purpose. If only for testing purposes, let's put the impl in a test package, not in the test directories, not the main directories
   - If we want to link so people can use from the existing vector classes (if we decide these are generally useful), let's keep it to something akin to BigIntVector.newBuilder() with the Builder object outside (but that is only if we think they are not for testing).
   - Let's support building with both boxed and unboxed types for primitives.
   
   In general, let's have these conversations before you go and write a couple hundred lines of code. Will waste less of your time.
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

emkornfield commented on issue #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693#issuecomment-544333923
 
 
   @jacques-n 
   
   > We really need to decide whether these are generally useful or for testing.
   
   My impression is we wouldn't want to encourage usage of these for general code, and there is already the Writer* classes for adding values?  Do you think there is a use-case for general purpose methods/builder class?  Maybe a discussion the ML.
   
   >  If generally useful, let's make them for general purpose. If only for testing purposes, let's put the impl in a test package, not in the test directories, not the main directories
   
   Can you clarify do you mean? A separate maven package or a testing java package under main? Or exporting a test jar from the arrow-vector class?  Possibly, relevant [SO question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/174560/sharing-test-code-in-maven#174670) 
   
   > If we want to link so people can use from the existing vector classes (if we decide these are generally useful), let's keep it to something akin to BigIntVector.newBuilder() with the Builder object outside (but that is only if we think they are not for testing).
   
   I think it is fine to have a separate builder if we think that it is valuable but I think that is orthogonal to simple static factory methods. 
   A good example of an API that has both is [Guava's Immutable Structures](https://guava.dev/releases/20.0/api/docs/com/google/common/collect/ImmutableMap.html).  Both static factories and builders have their place, and it make it convenient if they are both on the top level class.
   
   > Let's support building with both boxed and unboxed types for primitives.
   
   I think this only makes sense we make these general purpose.  Was there a use-case you were thinking of in particular for the testing scenario?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

jacques-n commented on issue #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693#issuecomment-544335948
 
 
   > My impression is we wouldn't want to encourage usage of these for general code, and there is already the Writer* classes for adding values? Do you think there is a use-case for general purpose methods/builder class? Maybe a discussion the ML.
   
   My comments were: if for test only, they shouldn't bleed into the non-test code (straight on vectors).
   
   > Can you clarify do you mean? A separate maven package or a testing java package under main? Or exporting a test jar from the arrow-vector class?
   I just meant put it in src/test/java, not src/main/java. We can depend on the test impls in other module via a maven test dependency if we want to use them outside vector module. We do that frequently at Dremio to use common test code without leaking it into main production code.
   
   
   > A good example of an API that has both is [Guava's Immutable Structures](https://guava.dev/releases/20.0/api/docs/com/google/common/collect/ImmutableMap.html). Both static factories and builders have their place, and it make it convenient if they are both on the top level class.
   
   To me that is the crux of the question. If for common use, linking a static method off of the vector classes make sense. If not, let's not. In the immutable case, the links are off the main class because the interfaces are for production use.
   
   
   > I think this only makes sense we make these general purpose. Was there a use-case you were thinking of in particular for the testing scenario?
   
   Yes, just general purpose. For test, agree that not important.
   
   My stance is basically:
   - if test only, avoid polluting non-test interfaces/codebase.
   - if not test, keep separate and just do a single link a'la builder. Since we use builder metaphor in C++ code, it might be nice to expose same concepts here. Also, if done via builder, maybe we could reuse/expand the ComplexWriter subtrees, etc rather than implementing an separate impl (just brainstorming here, not sure if this makes sense).
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

BryanCutler commented on issue #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693#issuecomment-544755486
 
 
   I'm kind of neutral on this change. If this ends up not just test-only, then I agree with @jacques-n and we should design a more comprehensive builder and reuse the ComplexWriter. It's not a good idea to have multiple ways to write to a vector that are similar.
   
   If this is just for test-only, I think trying to squeeze the test values in the same line to create the vector, that is already in a `try` statement, is too much and gets difficult to read for anything more than a couple of values. Most of the verbosity is in the calls to `allocateNew`, `setValueCount` and I'd rather see something like this that would make it easier to set some values at once.
   
   ```java
   // Create vector like before
   try (final IntVector v = new IntVector("intVector", allocator)) {
   
     // calls `allocateNew`, `setValueCount`, `setSafe`
     setVector(v, 1, 2);
     ...
   }
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

BryanCutler commented on issue #5693: ARROW-6930: [Java] Create static factory methods for common array types of testing.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5693#issuecomment-544755486
 
 
   I'm kind of neutral on this change. If this ends up not just test-only, then I agree with @jacques-n and we should design a more comprehensive builder and reuse the ComplexWriter. It's not a good idea to have multiple ways to write to a vector that are similar.
   
   If this is just for test-only, I think trying to squeeze the test values in the same line to create the vector, that is already in a `try` statement, is too much and gets difficult to read for anything more than a couple of values. Most of the verbosity is in the calls to `allocateNew`, `setValueCount` and I'd rather see something like this that would make it easier to set some values at once.
   
   ```java
   // Create vector like before
   try (final IntVector v = new IntVector("intVector", allocator)) {
   
     // calls `allocateNew`, `setValueCount`, `setSafe`
     setVector(v, 1, 2);
     ...
   }
   ```
   
   +1 to discuss a more detailed design on the mailing list

fields.summary: [Java] Create utility class for populating vector values used for test purpose only

comments.body: these should probably have an annotation to indicate they are for testing only.
